feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 17 at 3:58PM AKDT until March 18 at 8:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM AKDT FRIDAY... * WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Visibilities reduced to one half mile or less at times. Additional snow accumulations of up to 5 inches. Northwest winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts as high as 60 mph. * WHERE...Alaska Peninsula.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 17 at 3:00PM AKDT until March 18 at 12:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKDT FRIDAY... * WHAT...Blowing snow with low visibility and cold wind chills occuring. Plan on areas of poor visibilities to create difficult travel conditions at times. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph will cause areas of blowing and drifting snow. Visibility one half mile or less at times. Wind chills to 40 below.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 17 at 3:00PM AKDT until March 18 at 12:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKDT FRIDAY... * WHAT...Blowing snow with low visibility and wind chills to 40 below occuring. Plan on areas of poor visibilities to create difficult travel conditions at times. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph will cause areas of blowing and drifting snow. Visibility will be on half mile or less at times. Wind chills to 45 below.
entry.cap:areaDesc: St Lawrence Island and Bering Strait Coast

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 17 at 2:49PM AKDT until March 18 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM TO 1 PM AKDT FRIDAY... * WHAT...Very cold wind chills to 50 below expected. The cold wind chills will cause frostbite in as little as 10 minutes to exposed skin. * WHERE...Central Beaufort Sea Coast. * WHEN...4 AM to 1 PM Friday.

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 17 at 2:49PM AKDT until March 18 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 17 at 3:34PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...MODEST SYSTEM WITH LIGHT SNOW AND BREEZES THIS WEEKEND... A fast moving storm system will move across the region Saturday into early Sunday, bringing breezy winds with chances for rain and snow showers Saturday into Saturday evening, followed by chilly conditions with brisk northwest to north winds Sunday. * SNOW: Projected snowfall amounts are up to 3 inches above 5000
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Mono; Surprise Valley California

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 17 at 2:22PM PDT until March 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Showers Return to the Sierra on Saturday... .Another quick-hitting system will impact northern California on Saturday, and will bring winter weather conditions to the mountains. Relatively light snow amounts are forecast for the northern Sierra Nevada with impacts focused on weekend travel delays and possible chain controls. Snow levels will range from
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burney Basin, Eastern Shasta County; West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada; Western Plumas County, Lassen Park

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 17 at 11:57PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Areas of fog through the early morning hours... Areas of dense fog are being observed across portions of east central New York and western New England, lowering visibilities to a quarter of a mile or less in some locations. Fog is expected to last through sunrise. Motorists should exercise caution and be prepared for rapidly

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 17 at 11:20PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...LOCALLY DENSE FOG OVERNIGHT... Areas of fog will persist overnight across southern New England. Some of this fog may be locally dense, with visibility of one quarter mile or less. Dense fog may become more widespread early Friday morning. Motorists should exercise caution and be prepared for rapidly

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 17 at 7:44PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...PATCHY DENSE FOG... Areas of fog are being observed across the area, with patchy dense fog lowering visibilities to a quarter of a mile in some locations. Fog is expected to last through the night and dense fog may become more widespread over the next several hours. Motorists should exercise caution and be prepared for rapidly
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Fairfield; Northern Middlesex; Northern New Haven; Northern New London; Southern Fairfield; Southern Middlesex; Southern New Haven; Southern New London

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 17 at 8:34PM CDT until March 18 at 4:00PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Heavy Wet Snow Developing Overnight... .Low pressure in the Southern Plains will spread rain into Iowa tonight. The rain will change to snow across the advisory area in the predawn hours and continue through the day. Travel may become difficult at times with slick roads along with winds gusting to 35 mph which will reduce visibility Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Adair; Adams; Cass; Dallas; Guthrie; Madison; Taylor; Union

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 17 at 11:00PM CDT until March 18 at 4:00PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Threat for Rapidly Spreading Wildfires Increasing Friday... .The combination of gusty north winds, very low humidity, very dry grasses and brush, and warm temperatures will allow for any wildfire activity to spread rapidly late Friday morning through Friday afternoon. Residents should be very vigilant with items that could create sparks and ignite the dry grasses and brush.
